title: 108_hr2539
content:
The "Violence Against Children Act of 2003" may be cited as such. Congress finds that individuals under 18 account for a significant portion of crime victims, especially in sex crimes and kidnappings. Adolescents aged 12-17 are more than twice as likely to be victims of violent crime compared to adults. Only 28% of crimes against children are reported, leading to a significant underreporting of abuse cases. Approximately 1,200 children die from abuse annually, with around 879,000 children being victims of abuse, which has long-lasting negative effects. Child abuse has long-lasting negative effects on children and families, including delayed development, depression, substance abuse, and increased likelihood of experiencing or perpetrating domestic violence as an adult. Most local agencies lack resources to protect children and families adequately. Failure to pay child support is a form of neglect, leading to children living in poverty. Failure to provide financial support for children can lead to them living in poverty, resulting in inadequate education, lack of quality healthcare, and affordable housing. TITLE I--ENHANCED FEDERAL ROLE IN CRIMES AGAINST CHILDREN: Enhanced penalties for crimes against children. Chapter 110 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new section on violence against children. It states that anyone who willfully injures or attempts to injure a person under 18 years of age by force or threat of force can face imprisonment for up to 10 years and fines. If death results from the offense, the perpetrator can be imprisoned for any term of years or for life. If death results from the offense or if the offense includes kidnapping, aggravated sexual abuse, or an attempt to kill, the perpetrator shall be imprisoned for any term of years or for life, and fined accordingly. These circumstances apply if the conduct occurs during the travel of the defendant or the victim. The defendant or victim's travel across state lines or using interstate commerce, or employing a firearm in connection with the offense, will result in penalties under this section, including imprisonment and fines as specified in section 1111 of this title. The offense under this section may result in penalties under section 1111 of this title if it involves interstate commerce or foreign commerce. The United States Sentencing Commission will enhance penalties for crimes against children under federal law. The Comptroller General will review state laws regarding penalties for crimes against children. States must review statutory penalties for crimes against children, including sentencing practices and enhanced penalties for child victims, and report findings to Congress. SEC. 102. ENHANCED ASSISTANCE FOR CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS AND PROSECUTIONS BY STATE AND LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS. The Attorney General shall provide assistance in criminal investigations or prosecutions of violent crimes against minors upon request from a State, Indian tribal government, or local government, prioritizing cases where resources are limited. If resources are insufficient, the Attorney General will prioritize requests for assistance in cases involving offenders who have committed crimes in multiple states and rural jurisdictions facing financial challenges in investigating or prosecuting crimes. TITLE II--GRANT PROGRAMS

SEC. 201. FEDERAL ASSISTANCE TO STATE AND LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT. The Attorney General awards grants to assist in law enforcement and prosecution of crimes against children, providing personnel, training, technical assistance, and equipment for apprehension and adjudication of offenders. Training is focused on improving identification and response to crimes against children by law enforcement, prosecutors, judges, and court personnel. The Attorney General awards grants to assist in training law enforcement officers, prosecutors, judges, and other court personnel to effectively identify and respond to crimes against children. This includes developing specialized units and implementing policies devoted to preventing, identifying, and responding to crimes against children. Additionally, grants support the development of data collection and communication systems for better coordination in addressing these crimes. The Attorney General awards grants for training law enforcement to respond to crimes against children, including developing data systems for tracking arrests and convictions, enhancing collaboration between agencies, and strengthening programs for child victims. The Attorney General awards grants for training law enforcement to respond to crimes against children, including developing data systems for tracking arrests and convictions, enhancing collaboration between agencies, and strengthening programs for child victims. States, Indian tribal governments, or units of local government seeking grants must submit applications with required information to the Attorney General. The grants aim to improve care, treatment, and services for child victims and address the needs of Indian tribes dealing with crimes against children. The Attorney General awards grants for training law enforcement to respond to crimes against children. States, Indian tribal governments, or local government units applying for grants must provide necessary information. This includes describing the grant's purposes, intended use of funds, and expected results. They must also demonstrate a plan for implementing the grant. The grant applicants must consult with victim services programs experienced in helping children, and ensure that federal funds supplement non-federal funds without replacing them. Authorization of Appropriations.--$25,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated annually from 2004 to 2008 to supplement non-federal funds for activities under this section, ensuring compliance with specific regulations. SEC. 202. EDUCATION, PREVENTION, AND VICTIMS' ASSISTANCE GRANTS. The Attorney General awards grants for education, prevention, intervention, and victims' assistance services for crimes against children. Grants are used for seminars, hotlines, and training programs. The Attorney General awards grants for education, prevention, intervention, and victims' assistance services for crimes against children, including educational seminars, hotlines, training programs, informational materials, intervention services, awareness efforts, emergency medical treatment, and counseling for victims and their families. The Attorney General awards grants for education, prevention, intervention, and victims' assistance services for crimes against children, including emergency medical treatment, counseling for victims and their families, and increasing mental health professionals specializing in victims of crimes against children. Entities seeking grants must submit an application to the Attorney General. Entities applying for grants under this section must provide the Attorney General with necessary information, including the purposes, intended use, and expected results of the grant funds. Entities applying for grants must demonstrate consultation with victim services programs experienced in helping children, as part of their plan to implement the grant. Entities applying for grants must show experience in providing services to victims of crimes against children, including education, prevention, and intervention services. They must also certify the receipt of Federal funds under this program. Entities applying for grants must demonstrate experience in providing services to victims of crimes against children, including education, prevention, and intervention services. They must also certify that any Federal funds received will supplement non-Federal funds and that the funds will not supplant existing resources, with the possibility of a waiver in exceptional circumstances for nongovernmental organizations. Authorization of Appropriations: $25,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2008 to carry out the section on grants for victims of crimes against children. Compliance with section 303 is required for the State, Indian tribal government, or nongovernmental organization involved. TITLE III--NATIONWIDE PROGRAMS

SEC. 301. NATIONWIDE AMBER ALERT.

Each State receiving grants must establish a statewide AMBER Alert network for child abduction cases within 3 years.

SEC. 302. IMPROVED STATISTICAL GATHERING.

States must use or develop protocols to use the National Incident-Based Reporting System.

SEC. 303. NATIONAL SAFE HAVEN. Each State receiving grants under this Act must have a statute allowing parents to leave a newborn with a hospital employee anonymously without penalty, collect family medical history with parent approval, and involve law enforcement after child relinquishment. The State must search missing person databases after a child is relinquished under the Safe Haven law and publicize the law. An exception allows denying anonymity if a newborn shows signs of abuse. SEC. 304. IMPROVED CHILD PROTECTION SERVICES PROGRAMS. States must submit a report on their child welfare services program to the Secretary of Health and Human Services within 180 days of receiving funding. The General Accounting Office will also report to Congress on State practices and policies in the child welfare program. The General Accounting Office will report to Congress on State practices and policies in the child welfare program funded under subpart 1 of part B of title IV of the Social Security Act. The report will cover how States maintain records and verify the well-being of children, the impact of the review system by the Secretary of Health and Human Services on State reforms, and the best practices implemented by States. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is assisting States in reforming their child welfare system by implementing best practices and recommending legislative changes to Congress. TITLE IV--CHILD SUPPORT ENFORCEMENT

SENSE OF THE SENATE ON TAX TREATMENT OF CHILD SUPPORT: Congress should pass legislation to extend Federal tax treatment to nonpayment of child support by allowing deductions for recipients and adding unpaid amounts to the income of non-paying parents for tax purposes.
